title: Leah Bracknell hoped for an ‘impossible miracle’ right to the end... sadly it was not to be
text:

Just weeks before she died, former Emmerdale star Leah Bracknell spoke of her hopes for an “impossible miracle”.

But sadly that was not to be as the much loved actress’ family revealed today she passed away last month after suffering from lung cancer.

Leah, 55, was diagnosed with stage 4 of the disease in 2016. But although she was told her condition was terminal, she refused to focus on death and instead chose to focus on living.

From her complete positivity when I spoke to Leah in August, I never imagined it would be her last interview.

She said: “I still hope I could get my impossible miracle. And if not, I am going to have a bloody good time along the way.

“I don’t need to go and fulfil a bucket list, that’s not my style, I just want to do the things I want to do while I am healthy and strong, I won’t let myself live in fear, I’m just going to live a good life.”

Leah was best known for her role as Emmerdale’s Zoe Tate, the soap character she played for almost 16 years from December 1989.

She was devoted to her grown-up daughters Maya and Lily, and her husband Jez Hughes - she called him her “rock” - and who she quietly married in 2017 six months after her diagnosis.

(Image: Ken McKay/ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

Today her agent released a statement saying: “It is with the deepest sadness that Leah Bracknell’s family confirm that Leah passed away in September, three years after her diagnosis with stage 4 lung cancer.

“They would like to thank all the public for their support and generosity which contributed to the extension and quality of her life over the past three years.

“Leah continued to embrace life and faced her illness with positivity. Leah had an energy and enthusiasm for life, a kind heart and much love to give to those around her.”

Tributes poured in from friends and co-stars across the acting industry, with all of them citing her caring nature as well as her talent as an actress.

Mandy Dingle actress Lisa Riley, who worked with Leah on the Emmerdale, said: “Leah lived her life to the fullest, her legacy will truly live on.

"She played my fairy godmother in Emmerdale and that’s what she was in real life too - there was nobody on that show that Leah didn’t help. She will be missed so much by everyone who knew her.”

Dominic Brunt, who plays vet Paddy Kirk in Emmerdale, tweeted: “I lost a good friend today. She was truly amazing in lots of different ways and I shall miss her x”

Adele Silva, who played Kelly Windsor in the show, tweeted: “#Leah what a truly lovely human being- such a sad loss.”

(Image: ITV)

And Coronation Street ’s Sally Ann Matthews, who plays Jenny Connor, tweeted: “So sorry to hear that the beautiful soul, Leah Bracknell, has lost her battle with cancer. The world has lost a little sparkle x”

Born Alison Rosalind Bracknell, she took the professional name Leah in honour of her Chinese-Malaysian actress mother Li-er Hwang.

Her father, television director David, gave Leah her first acting role in TV series The Chiffy Kids in 1976, before she took her future into her own hands.

Only two years after studying at Webber Douglas Academy of Dramatic Art and aged 25, she was cast in ITV’s Emmerdale.

John Whiston, managing director of continuing drama and head of ITV in the North, said: “Everyone on Emmerdale is very sad to hear of the death of Leah Bracknell. Leah was a hugely popular member of the Emmerdale cast for over 16 years.

“During that time she featured in some of the show’s most high profile and explosive plots and always delivered a pitch perfect performance. Zoe Tate was one of soaps first lesbian characters and Leah made sure the character was both exciting and credible.

“Leah herself was a very generous and caring colleague, much loved by cast and crew alike.”

(Image: ITV)

She left the series in 2005 in an episode voted the Best Exit at the British Soap Awards in May 2006.

But that certainly didn’t spell the end of her acting career, appearing in Judge John Deed, Casualty 1907, A Tuuch of Frost, DCI Banks, Doctors and another ITV1 soap, The Royal Today.

She also turned her attention to theatre, starring in both Gaslight and Strangers On A Train.

Her battle with cancer only came to light when he launched a Go Fund Me page to raise money for her to undergo treatment overseas.

Her first oncologist had told her she had just months to live. But she refused to contemplate death.

Using her experience as a yoga teacher and shamanic healer, she decided on a positive mindset, saying: “I sat myself down and thought, ‘How do I want to live now?’” she says.

“The focus is all on dying. So I thought, ‘How can I get the most out of my life, who do I want to be?’ You can still live a rich life whatever s*** is thrown at you.”

More than 2,500 fans joined together to raise £50,000 to help pay for cutting-edge treatment for her in Germany.

She thanked everyone involved, adding: “I really did not expect or feel deserving of such interest and kindness.”

(Image: Yorkshire Television)

But she never made it to Germany and instead underwent treatment here on the NHS, and was taking part in a clinical trial in the months before her death.

She launched a blog called Something Beginning With C about her cancer journey, through which she shared her hopes and fears, and was writing a book which she hoped would help other cancer sufferers and their families.

And she refused to be defined by traditional labels - instead taking inspiration from the Extinction Rebellion protests she attended over the summer despite her illness - and styled herself as a “cancer rebel”.

She explained: “A lot of the labels around cancer are very military - you battle cancer, you have got to keep fighting it.

“There is a lot of language is very negative and not very helpful for someone with cancer - I read headlines about myself and they would say things like cancer victim, cancer sufferer, cancer-stricken. But I didn’t recognise myself in that - that was not how I would describe myself.”

She really was no victim. Leah refused to listen to doctors’ prognosis, instead choosing to focus on living her best life.

(Image: REX/Shutterstock)

In that last interview, listening to her talk with such optimism about her illness and hope for the future was truly humbling.

Leah was most certainly a glass half full person, and she refused to be defined by her illness or let it stop her from enjoying life.

She spoke of setting an example to her two beloved daughters Maya and Lily of how to rise to life’s most extreme challenges.

As the family grieve together, there is no doubt that Leah’s spirit and positivity will live on through them just as she wanted.
description: Leah Bracknell, 55, was diagnosed with stage 4 of the disease in 2016. But although she was told her condition was terminal, she refused to focus on death and instead chose to focus on living.
